title: Where can I find out if a song is copyrighted? - Quora

response.answer_text: Rule of thumb says any song published by a major publisher (they are all part of Warners/HBO, Universal/NBC/Music Corporation of America, Sony/Colgems, Paramount/Famous Music, BMG) published after 1924 are probably still in copyright. Any song written after 1978 is DEFINITELY in copyright, even if no copyright form was filed. You can do a search at the Copyright Office/Library of Congress. You can even do an online search for songs written at least 15 years ago (they are kinda behind on filing things at the Library of Congress).

US LAW: If a song is written in the U.S. or by someone in the U.S., it is automatically covered under U.S. Copyright law once it has been set into tangible form - that is, once it has been written on paper or recorded, it has Copyright protections. The songwriter does not need to register it to have Copyright. If you want to know if a particular song has been registered, you can do a search on the database on Copyright.gov
